A while ago, I saw something that looks like it has a place in the 
future.  It was a demo of a programming environment called Subtext.

Subtext is really the intersection of a bunch of different ideas, but 
the key one, at least regarding testing and TDD, is that environments 
can really give us much more information than they do currently.  In 
Subtext, your program is represented in little graphic elements that are 
sort of like the cells in a spreadsheet.  The cool part is that as you 
manipulate your program, it is continually working on visible example 
values.  They change as you change your code in much the same way that a 
spreadsheet recalculates.

To me, it seems that this is a really a great idea to pursue.  When we 
do TDD, one of the benefits is the immediacy of feedback.  We type a 
test, we press a button and see it fail, we write some code and see it 
pass.  With one of these 'immediate' environments, you are working on 
examples the whole time, so it brings feedback to another level.  I 
suppose that example values could be captured as invariants (tests) as 
you write your code.

John Edwards (the guy behind Subtext) has a set of demos here: 
http://subtextual.org/
Here's a good one to start with: http://subtextual.org/demo1.html

At this point, Subtext is science fiction.  It's demo stage only.  
John's playing with the ideas and trying to get people interested in 
them.  But it's well worth a look.

In general, I think it would be great to see environments which give us 
much more information about our programs.  Another example.. a while ago 
I was talking to Ivan Moore (of Jester fame) and he was saying that he 
had an idea for a tool that would go through your Java code and 
'privitize' it; that is, make all methods private that could be 
private.  In the spirit of the thing he was thinking of calling it 
Thatcher :-)  We were talking about it with a few other people who, like 
me, are very annoyed by the fact that private gets in the way when its 
in someone else's mangled code and you don't have the opportunity to 
peel it off, and we thought, well, wouldn't it be nice if your 
environment just told you which methods weren't used elsewhere in the 
system?  Sort of, "this one could be private if you wanted it to be."

TDD has this neat emotional feel..  you work in little transactions with 
the code.. and you get a lot of feedback.  I think that there are more 
opportunities for that sort of feedback if we make our environments smarter.
